ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to write an investigative piece, interview people who have dealt with trauma, access publicly available documents, and the history of journalism and its effect on society.
How to ask meaningful questions beyond the surface and how to express the found answers in a seamless manner.

I learned all the steps and skills for conducting a thorough investigative report, including research, reporting, organizing information, fact-checking, and ethical limitations. I also gained knowledge about the history of journalism, the ethical dilemmas, and the legal overlap.
I learned how to conduct extensive research, as well as interviewing methods for different people.
I learned how to report and read reports on serious investigations.

I developed skills that were valuable across the board. I knew people who were taking this course because they needed a writing credit and this was outside of their comfort zones, and they thrived just as much as the aspiring journalists in the class! Even online, there was a human connection among my classmates. We always shared insightful discussions and it was great knowing that the work we did was actual, valuable work that journalists would do. We ACTUALLY interviewed people, we ACTUALLY did research, we did it all.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I liked how this class cumulated to a final paper that we worked on.

The strength was the depth of information provided and the quality of activities. We learned about journalism from all angles and exercised these skills in a real report. The weakness was organization. I think it would have been helpful for all assignments to posted in Canvas ahead of time.

The biggest strength were the uniqueness of the lectures, such as on trauma and journalism and media law. The syllabus readings were excellent, wish we would've had a chance to discuss more of them. Though I understand the importance of working in a group, the team nature of a project we worked on all term was frustrating. Course materials sometimes unorganized at times--think class would've functioned better as more shorter sessions than 2 3hr sessions/week.
This course does a good job keeping students engaged and having us apply the taught content in journalism.
The course was very engaging and it taught me a lot about consuming news.

The strength of the class is Professor Shapiro. He's passionate about journalism and especially about the history and ethics surrounding the field. The only weakness is that he's typically late in grading and in announcements, which led to some confusion about readings that we had to do and what we needed to complete.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you are interested in journalism and want to learn how to write an investigative journalism piece.
Yes! The course was very enjoyable and almost felt like an adventure into our own real reporting.
Yes, It was very interesting and useful if a student is interested in journalism.
Yes. This course helped me advance my research capabilities and taught me how to best talk to people who are facing trauma.
I would recommend it to anyone interested in journalism because we did actual field work and it felt informative and practical.

I would highly recommend this course to any student, aspiring journalist or not. It's so valuable to investigate and to learn more about the community around you in a way that transcends textbooks and readings. YOU'RE almost teaching yourself about the things you're writing about, and that's what's truly special about this class. You are working in the field!
